title: Former Thinx CEO accused of groping employees’ breasts | New York Post
text:
The former chief executive of Thinx, a maker of lingerie for menstruating women, has been slammed with a slew of graphic sex-harassment allegations.
CEO Miki Agrawal grabbed her employees’ breasts, gabbed profusely about her sex life in the office, got undressed in front of workers and video-dialed them while using the bathroom and lying in bed naked, according to a former employee.
Agrawal — a self-proclaimed “She-EO” who has long traded on feminist principles — has denied the allegations, filed with the City of New York Commission on Human Rights, saying many of her actions and conversations had been taken out of context.
Still, Agrawal reportedly stepped down as CEO after Thinx’s board investigated, although she is still currently employed by the company.
The accusations, made former Thinx employee Chelsea Leibow, include claims that Agrawal touched Leibow’s breasts without her consent.
Because of Agrawal’s “aggressive and retaliatory demeanor, position of authority and style of management,’” Leibow says she was afraid of speaking up for herself while enduring the harassment.
Agrawal was also accused of fat-shaming employees.
New York magazine reported Monday that Agrawal recounted to employees her sexual exploits at an “Orgy Dome” at the Burning Man festival in explicit detail, and left one of her breasts completely exposed while talking to a worker.
A story last week by fashion blog Racked, meanwhile, had also alleged a culture of harassment and intimidation under Agrawal, who doled out “substandard pay, flimsy benefits, and scarce perks,” according to the article.
In response to the Racked story, Agrawal published a Medium post on Friday, saying, “Yes, I have made a TON of mistakes along the way but I can proudly say that our company has grown from an idea in my head to an innovation that is worn by millions of satisfied women globally in a few short years.”
